comments:
If I make a new plugin project with the wizard (entering an arbitrary name and
accepting all defaults), I'm unable to launch a runtime workbench.

In the log, it shows:
java.lang.RuntimeException: Application "org.eclipse.ui.workbench" could not be
found in the registry.

Adding plugin dependencies and starting up installed plugins doesn't seem to help.

I'm having this problem in 3.0 M9 and 3.0 RC1 on WinXP, but not 3.0 M7. 

I'm having the same problem with two existing plugins projects that have been
migrated to 3.0.

The full log reads:

!SESSION Jun 11, 2004 14:30:56.936 ---------------------------------------------
eclipse.buildId=unknown
java.version=1.4.2
java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc.
BootLoader constants: OS=win32, ARCH=x86, WS=win32, NL=en_US
!ENTRY org.eclipse.osgi Jun 11, 2004 14:30:56.936
!MESSAGE Application error
!STACK 1
java.lang.RuntimeException: Application "org.eclipse.ui.workbench" could not be
found in the registry. The applications available are:
org.eclipse.ant.core.antRunner, org.eclipse.help.base.infocenterApplication,
org.eclipse.help.base.helpApplication, org.eclipse.help.base.indexTool,
org.eclipse.pde.build.BuildScriptGenerator,
org.eclipse.pde.build.FetchScriptGenerator,
org.eclipse.pde.junit.runtime.uitestapplication,
org.eclipse.pde.junit.runtime.legacyUItestapplication,
org.eclipse.pde.junit.runtime.coretestapplication, org.eclipse.ui.ide.workbench,
org.eclipse.update.core.standaloneUpdate.
	at
org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.PlatformActivator$1.run(PlatformActivator.java:324)
	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:273)
	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:128)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
	at
sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:324)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:185)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:638)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:622)

see also:
news://news.eclipse.org:119/cad007$sar$1@eclipse.org
news://news.eclipse.org:119/ca7o2s$543$1@eclipse.org

and possibly
news://news.eclipse.org:119/c8vqit$rld$1@eclipse.org
news://news.eclipse.org:119/c870tu$oed$1@eclipse.org

Here's an update:
1) The problem only rears its head when using a workspace outside the eclipse
install (whether specified through a "-data *workspacepath*" or the workspace
chooser).  It doesn't happen when the workspace is ..\eclipse\workspace

2) It still happens in RC2

There is no org.eclipse.ui.workbench application. It has been replaced by
org.eclipse.ui.ide.workbench. It seems you are using an old launch configuration
that was created at the time org.eclipse.ui.workbench was the Workbench's
application id. Just go to your launch configuration and ensure the right
application id is selected there.

Is that what is happening with you?

Nope, the application running is org.eclipse.ui.ide.workbench in the
configuration.  Everything in the configuration are just defaults.  I'm running
into the problem from a fresh install.

I think that this bug should be really easy to replicate. Just:
1) Start with a fresh installation of M9, RC1 or RC2
2) On startup choose a workspace outside of the installation path (Eclipse in
C:\eclipse and the workspace in C:\sandbox)
3) Go to the workbench and open the PDE perspective
4) File > New > Plug-in Project
5) Enter any name for the project ("foo")
6) Accept all other defaults (Next, Finish)
7) On the overview page that opens, click Launch a Runtime Workbench

The runtime workbench fails with the option to view the log posted previously.

Are you able to replicate this behavior?  These are the only steps necessary
that I've run into.

No, I am not. Running with an workspace outside the Eclipse install is the
recommended setup, so I would be surprised if that caused any problems.

I believe there must be some problem with the Runtime Workbench launch
configuration you have in the c:\sandbox workspace. Please try the following:

1 - In the Java or Plugin perspectives, open the launch configuration management
dialog (Run -> Run...)
2 - select the "Run-time Workbench" category, *not* the launch configuration
named "Run-time Workbench"
3 - Press "New"
4 - Run the just created launch configuration (named New_Configuration...) by
pressing Run.

Does it work?

No, the new configuration ("New Configuration (1)") produces exactly the same
results.

I'm really suprised that you weren't able to replicate the behavior.  I've
tested the procedure several times with M9, RC1 and RC2.  Did you start with a
fresh install and a new workspace?

Just did that again using RC1. Everything works fine. There seems to be
something wrong with your install. The message referring to a
"org.eclipse.ui.workbench" application is very suspicious.

Do you have any plugins/features installed other than the ones in the Eclipse
SDK? How did you "install" RC1? Extracted it to an empty directory, or on top of
an existing install (that is not supported)?

I'm extracting it into an empty directory.

This is getting increasingly subtle.  I installed eclipse on a Win2k Pro box and
everthing was fine.

On my computer, I rename the directory containing the old install of eclipse and
extract a new one.  (Rename C:\dev\eclipse to C:\dev\eclipse_old and extract the
new install to C:\dev)

It looks like eclipse must be reading my other workspaces.  They are all in
C:\sandbox.

If I use a workspace called C:\temp\absolutelynewworkspace everything is fine.
If I use a workspace called C:\sandbox\absolutelynewworkspace I have problems.
If I move all my old legacy workspaces in C:\sandbox to C:\sandbox\old and use a
workspace called C:\sandbox\absolutelynewworkspace everything is fine.
Then, if I move all my old workspaces back from C:\sandbox\old to C:\sandbox and
delete C:\sandbox\absolutelynewworkspace, then startup using a workspace called
C:\sandbox\absolutelynewworkspace, everything is broken again.

I sanity checked that it doesn't have anything to do with a legacy
runtime-workspace.

This is definitely a bug, but to my mind is rapidly dropping in priority.  At
least I'm confident that users of my plug-in are *very* unlikely to run into the
same problem.

What do you think?

Found it

looks like I had a year-old copy of the "features" directory from the 2.0 / 2.1
days in my C:\sandbox folder at the same level as the workspace and eclipse only
recently started trying to load it.

I don't know that eclipse should try to load features from this directory.  It
might also be trying to load plugins if there was a "plugins" directory, but I
haven't tried it.

I'll leave the status of this bug to your discretion.  Thanks *so* much for your
time and attention Rafael! :)

That usually happens if your launch configuration has the "Use features in the
workspace (simulated normal startup)" option, in the plugins tab. Since that is
not the default, you should not have that option set. Can you confirm that you
are *not* using that option?

It is not checked

To my knowledge, this would only load a feature (org.eclipse.platform-feature)
if it was in the workspace
(C:\sandbox\absolutelynewworkspace\org.eclipse.platform-feature).

It appears that the runtime workbench is loading it from
C:\sandbox\features\org.eclipse.platform-feature which is not in the workspace
(C:\sandbox\absolutelynewworkspace).

Nope,

I moved the feature to the Win2k box and cannot replicate the problem.

Created an attachment (id=12081)
features directory for test case to replicate problem

extract in the same directory as the workspace NOT within the workspace
directory

whoops,

I was able to replicate the problem.  I hadn't copied over the contents of the
directory due to permission problems.  See the attached features directory above.

I could not reproduce... what I did (with RC1):

- extracted the contents of attachment 12081 to d:\sandbox (preserving paths, so
the platform feature will be at d:\sandbox\features\org.eclipse.platform-feature)
- started Eclipse selecting d:\sandbox\workspace as my dev workspace
- created a new plugin
- started a runtime workbench using the link available off the Overview page (a
target workspace is created at d:\sandbox\runtime-workbench-workspace)

Result: Eclipse comes up without any problems. Did I miss any step?
That should have done it.  Maybe try restarting eclipse?

Nope... can you reproduce it with the same steps I executed? Would be better if
you used another location (other than "sandbox"), add the feature there, and
tried to reproduce it with 3.0 RC1 freshly installed
(<eclipse_home>/configuration has only a config.ini file, no subdirs, no
3rd-party plug-ins/features). Thanks.

A new workspace would be cool, too. Whatever base location you choose, it should
be empty before you start to put things there.

It worked for me.  I used RC2, since that was easier to find.  I'll track down
RC1 and give it another go after I fire this off.

Created C:\temp\eclipsebug directory
Extracted eclipse RC2 and features.zip into the directory
created directory workspace so that the contents of C:\temp\eclipsebug is
-eclipse
-features
-workspace

Fired up eclipse by double clicking on it.  Go to workspace.  Window > Open
Perspective > Other > PDE Perspective.  File > New > Plugin Project.  Enter
"foo" as the name, Next, Finish.  Click on the link on the overview page to
start a new runtime-workbench.

runtime-workbench fails

I'll give RC1 a try and give an update.

In my last post, when I said it worked that was a misnomer.  RC2 failed.  I
tried RC1 and it did not fail.  I tried another install of RC2 using the above
procedure in another directory and it failed again.  Can you try RC2?

I finally could reproduce. Thanks for the information. 

It seems that PDE is adding the workspace's parent directory to the list of
sites in the generated platform.xml. Is that intended? I guess it does not make
sense when the launch configuration is *not* using the "simulated startup" style.

Moving to PDE.
Great! Thanks again for your help.

Although not exactly a duplicate, the fix for bug 66266 will address this one 
as well.

*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 66266 ***
See bug 66266 comment #11 for an explanation.

traces.message: Application "org.eclipse.ui.workbench" could not be found in the registry. The applications available are: org.eclipse.ant.core.antRunner, org.eclipse.help.base.infocenterApplication, org.eclipse.help.base.helpApplication, org.eclipse.help.base.indexTool, org.eclipse.pde.build.BuildScriptGenerator, org.eclipse.pde.build.FetchScriptGenerator, org.eclipse.pde.junit.runtime.uitestapplication, org.eclipse.pde.junit.runtime.legacyUItestapplication, org.eclipse.pde.junit.runtime.coretestapplication, org.eclipse.ui.ide.workbench, org.eclipse.update.core.standaloneUpdate.
